subject: Religion & Spirituality
subcategory: Sacred Texts That Shaped the World
title: Intertextuality: How Scriptures Talk to Each Other
description: A quick win: understand Intertextuality: How Scriptures Talk to Each Other.

hook.text: The Quran references the Bible. The Bible echoes Gilgamesh. Sacred texts are a conversation, not isolated monologues.

buildup.text: Jesus quotes the Torah. Muhammad affirms Moses and Jesus. Buddhist sutras echo Hindu concepts. Texts build on texts.

discovery.text: No scripture was written in a vacuum. Each responds to earlier traditions, sometimes agreeing, sometimes arguing.

twist.text: Religions that claim to be unique often share borrowed stories. Originality in scripture is rarer than believers want.

climax.text: Sacred texts are a global conversation across millennia. Understanding one requires knowing the others it's talking to.

punchline.text: Scriptures quote each other. Religion is a conversation, not a monologue.

quiz.question: How do sacred texts relate to each other?
options: They reference, borrow from, and respond to earlier religious texts
They all say the same thing
